utterances: (Soundbite of laughter)
Where did you Cara from?
Irene Cara?
You know, I - that was part of it.
Like mortifyingly enough.
You know, I really loved ""Fame"" and what - you know all the (unintelligible).
I'm going to live forever, yeah.
You know what I mean?
Yeah.
So I loved all that stuff.
And then also there was a really, like, this girl, who was in my junior high class.
She also was named Kara.
And I was, kind of, thought she was cool.
She spelled it with a K, I spelled it with a C.
So I think it was like a combination of things, but…
And when did you decide to go back to Strawberry?
Well, it was my senior year of high school.
We moved back to California, thankfully.
And I was really happy about that.
And I believe it was, kind of, a spontaneous decision on the first day of school.

I am - basically, I went to every class and they called out my name as Cara and I - I guess it was a really good trial by fire, but I - in every single class I'd say no, actually my name is Strawberry.
And after that I went to every class and they called out my name as Cara.
And I - I guess it was really a good trial by fire, but I - in every single class I'd say no, actually my name is Strawberry.
And after that, it was a really kind of a liberating thing I have to say.
It was like just kind of going back to who I really was, in this way, which did kind of test me in terms of having to really proclaim that in front of 30 people, five times in one day.
It was kind of a big deal.
And you have the double whammy, of course, you have a famous last name, your grandfather was the great writer William Saroyan.
Right.
And how does that play in that, you know, does one name deflect from the other?
Well, my mother had a great kind of take on this.
She basically said I was on, it was like, I - when my book came out, I got, you know, various publicity, kind of, thing's going.
Sure.

And I was on page six and it was like some kind of, you know, really light thing about like all the famous people I mentioned in my book, which is really not what my book is about at all, it's like one page, mentions a couple of people.
But she said, you know - and there was a picture of me.
And it was just kind of like a light take on who I was.
And she said, you know, the thing is - yeah, that basically it's nice because it balances out.
You know, the - if I was named Strawberry Smith, it might be like, you know, people could kind of write it off.
But also, if I'm just named Jane Saroyan, it's sort…
Yeah.
…of a bit like all about the Saroyan name, you know.
So, you get a little bit of both, that works out good for you.
Yes, it does.
Yeah.
Well, I know from reading your piece that I won't be the first to say, nice to eat you.
